advice_levels.onscreen_text: Enemy trade ships are fair game in times of war. Right-click on a trade route to draw additional income from raiding their trade fleets.
Iyo has a port. A port provides income, and can construct ships for trade and your fleet. You should construct a ship to patrol your coastal waters. Select the port of Matsuyama now.

If a flanking manoeuvre by cavalry is countered, for example by enemy infantry moving to intercept, abort the move but leave them in a threatening position. You will have tied down some of their units for no cost.

Guard mode ensures that units fight defensively, try to maintain their formation when attacked and won't pursue the enemy if they run away. It can be toggled on or off by selecting a unit and clicking on the guard mode button that appears in the bottom left-hand corner of the screen.

Feigning a rout by sacrificing a unit is a sure way of enticing a defender out of a strong defensive position, or luring an attacker into an ambush. Beware though, a feigned rout can quickly become a real one.
Use backspace on your keyboard to stop the movement of our armies, fleets and agents on the campaign map.

The penalty for breaking an alliance gradually degrades over time, but is higher if there were trade agreements in place when the betrayal occurred. If you are thinking of attacking an ally, cancel the alliance and trade agreement between you. Also, wait for any hostages held by them to be returned, otherwise they will be executed when you declare war.

Skirmishers begin the battle with skirmish mode turned on, meaning that they'll try to avoid hand to hand contact with the enemy by retreating to a safe firing distance. Try to keep some melee troops close behind them, so your skirmishers can run back through their lines to safety when threatened.
Killing their general early on will deliver a heavy blow to the enemy army's morale in the field.
Your army will march on Iyo. As the province's castle town, is far away from Tosa, it may take more than one season to get there, as shown by the number of direction arrows.

The Miyoshi are no more. Peace can return, crops be gathered, and men may work without fear. But how long will peace last? The Shogunate, and Japan, are within your grasp. Perhaps this is not the time for contemplation, but a time for total war! The tutorial is done. Now, fight on!
An army on board your fleet can be a naval invasion force. Castles and armies near the coast can be attacked from your ships if their zone of control overlaps the coastline.

Right-click to move our fleet to any part of the highlighted area. We can attack a fleet belonging to another clan when it is within the highlighted area by right-clicking on it. To disembark any passengers move the fleet to a coast and right-click on the land. Alternatively select the unit, units, agent or agents you wish to disembark and right-click on the shore.

Your ally will keep the hostage for two years after the deal is done. The captive cannot do anything during that time. At the end of the agreement, the hostage is returned to you and the alliance continues. If the agreement is broken, the hostage dies!

Press this button to repair damaged ships in the midst of a battle. Unless the damage is too great this will task the crew with fixing the problem. Ordering repairs to a ship will stop it from being able to carry out other tasks and leave it vulnerable to attack. Once a ship is carrying out repairs, giving an order to carry out any other actions will cancel that order.

It is time to move on to the next turn. As you end this turn, your orders will be carried out and other clans will carry out their own actions. They will develop their lands and move armies before you regain control. Click the end turn button now.
This panel gives you important information about a particular unit type: number of men, recruitment and upkeep costs, experience, statistics, special abilities, and a detailed description.

This option is used to broker military alliances. This allows us to call on an ally to provide assistance when at war, and likewise. Note that a refusal to provide support when an ally is under attack will instantly cancel the alliance between us.

Often the best tactic is to encircle the enemy and shoot them from behind or in the flanks. If they turn or chase you off, their formation will be disrupted, leaving them vulnerable to the attentions of your cavalry.

The mobility and stamina of light cavalry makes them ideally suited to scouting the battlefield. If they stumble into a sticky situation their light mounts should be swift enough to get them clear of danger.
Now you are known on the mainland it would be sensible to trade with one of Honshu's clans. Select the diplomacy button in the bottom right-hand corner of the screen.

This battle can be fought as a drop-in battle. This means that you can choose to have another player take command of the AI forces in the battle, offering an even greater challenge! Click the drop-in battle button to quickly find an opponent on-line or invite a friend.

In Total War: Shogun 2, turns are represented by the four seasons: spring, summer, autumn and winter. To check the season or the date, mouse over the end turn button at the bottom right-hand side of the screen.
There is a Kono monk near Tosa! What are his intentions? Click the clan tab below the radar map to see your clan's diplomatic relations.
Light cavalry make excellent bait. You can lure the enemy into ambushes, draw units out of position in their line, or just make them tire themselves out chasing you.

A drop-in battle is a feature allowing you to find a human opponent to take the place of the AI clan in a battle in your campaign, or fight a battle in another's campaign in place of the AI. This is achieved via the on-line battle mechanism. Further details about this feature are available through the encyclopaedia, accessed through the dedicated button in the top left-hand corner of the screen.

Control of the camera on the campaign map is simple. Use W to move the camera forward and S to move it backward. A and D strafe sideways. Q and E rotate. Alternatively, hold down the mouse wheel and drag, or move the mouse to the edge of the screen to pull the map in that direction. Use X and Z or the mouse wheel to zoom in closer.

There is a port in this province that has not been developed to its full potential. Port upgrades enable the construction of bigger and better ships, as well as trade with foreign powers and increased income.

The farms across our territory are not producing enough food to supply all our castle towns, resulting in food shortages in some provinces. As a matter of urgency, upgrade farms in any province to improve food supply, as persistent hunger will lead to an increase in discontent.

You can view your clan's fame, clan traits, diplomatic relations, current missions and victory conditions here. All daimyo want to become Shogun. And so does Chosokabe Motochika. If Shikoku island is united under him, your fame will be felt in Kyoto!

Your upgrade is under construction. After a castle town has been attacked, some buildings will be damaged and lose their effects. On the construction tab select the damaged building's card, and then click on the building repair button to the left.

This may be a problem! Your people are restless, unhappy at the taxes they must pay. The clan raised taxes to pay for its wars, but you should reduce tax levels to keep public order. Click on the tick button to close this event.
Good: your yari ashigaru are now in the castle town garrison, fresh from training. Keep your castle town selected and select the province's army tab at the bottom of the screen.

Maintaining a unit's courage and discipline in the heat of battle is dependent on their morale - a measure of pride and belief in their abilities. This is boosted by training, experience and the presence of an inspirational general. Morale is weakest when a unit is heavily outnumbered or outmatched by an enemy. You can see their morale state just above their unit flag.
Where the enemy are concentrated, prepare a defensive line; where they are strong, avoid them. Attack where they are unprepared.
If you want to concentrate solely on the business of war, taxation can be automated by clicking in the checkbox on this tab.
When you outnumber the enemy greatly, surround and destroy them utterly. Show no mercy!

Lord, we have not mastered any of the new arts for some time and our rivals will be moving far ahead of us. Concepts that will give our clan the advantage can be developed on the mastery of the arts panel.

This tab shows all existing buildings in the selected castle town and surrounding province, mouse over them to see what can yet be constructed. Right-click on a picture to see its description. Left-click on a building to add it to the queue, and again to remove it. Construction cost is displayed underneath, construction time is shown in the top left-hand corner. Some buildings cannot be constructed until certain arts have been mastered. In these instances please go to the mastery of the arts panel to begin study.

Lower quality infantry are useful for engaging and holding the enemy in place while you go around their side or rear. However, the lower the troop quality, the less time you have before they break and rout.

Master, our clan is bankrupt because, as our empire has grown, the administrative infrastructure needed to efficiently tax it has not grown at the same rate. We can get back on course by disbanding redundant units and upgrading castles across our territory.
Master, suddenly attacking long-standing allies will have an effect on how the other clans view our own. They will be cautious when dealing with us in future.

When defending territory it is important to know how far enemy armies are able to move. Click on an enemy army to see its potential movement extent. When an army is blocking our path the terrain will be highlighted at the choke point. We must fight it to pass through or find an alternative route.
Wako are seaborne pirates who will attack trade routes and sap the income from them, especially if a route is inadequately patrolled by our fleets. Please remember to check for piracy each season.
Now the battle is done, this panel shows enemy casualties and your troops' gain in experience. Click the tick button to close the panel.

This is good: by the time your army reaches Sanuki, you will have mastered bushido. Remember to revisit the arts panel. You can learn the ways of chi to improve your economy and government. I will advise you again when you own Sanuki.

As taxes change, the province colour on the radar map changes from red to yellow and then green, if your people are very happy! The numbers beneath show the tax harvest for next season. High taxes add more to your treasury, but reduce the long-term economic growth of the province.
Lower quality infantry make great targets for the enemy to waste their missiles on. They can protect high value units by drawing fire.

Excellent, the Kono are dead, and Iyo is yours! The people of Iyo will resent having a new master. Do not loot the place, as this will hurt public order; instead, occupy Iyo to keep public order and use the province's buildings.

It is important to preserve the devastating impact a cavalry unit can have. When going into combat with cavalry, always charge the last few yards by double right-clicking on the target. Beware of charging across too great a distance though, it's a tiring business!

Ninja are skilful assassins. They can spy on your rivals, assassinate generals or agents, and sabotage buildings. They will remain hidden, unless they fail a mission or are spotted by the enemy. Select your ninja now.

You can master military and civil arts to benefit your clan and lands. Your troops may suffer low morale. Some arts can instil the discipline needed to face the enemy. Select bushido, the way of the warrior, to boost your troops' morale and ready them for battle.
The enemy will often try to flank your formation with cavalry, so it's a good idea to have infantry reserves on the ends of your line ready to intercept them.

The radar map allows an aerial view of the battle detailing the position of our units or ships and those enemies that are visible, and also topography to assist in planning an attack. Use the plus and minus buttons to zoom in or out and the button in the top right-hand corner to minimise or maximise it.
Tosa needs more than trained peasants to guard its walls! Samurai warriors are the answer, but they are recruited at a dojo. You need to build one. Now, select the province's construction tab.

Controlling the camera on the battlefield is simple. Dragging the mouse to the edge of the screen pulls the map in that direction. Use W to move the camera forward, and S to move it backward. A and D strafe sideways. Use X and Z or the mouse wheel to move the camera up and down, and the + and - buttons to tilt the view up or down.

Farms and other agricultural buildings increase both income and food supplies across all provinces under your control. It is essential to keep them upgraded in order to avoid food shortages at the castle towns.
Kono treachery cannot be tolerated! Act swiftly and destroy them! Select your entire army and then right-click on Iyo province to the north. This is a declaration of war!
Click the tick button to confirm the declaration. Click it again to close the panel.

The overall happiness of a population is influenced by a variety of different contributing factors, including tax levels, food shortages, the presence of entertainment and religious buildings, and repression through garrison size. Rebellion becomes a risk when the people are so unhappy that repression can no longer contain public order.
When attacking an enemy with superior missile troops, get into melee combat as quickly as possible.
When attacking across a river, try to soften up the enemy on the far bank by bombarding them with missiles first. Once they are weakened, your assault has a better chance of succeeding.
When troops are surrounded during hand-to-hand combat, they will fight to the death as they have nowhere left to run! Beware though, as desperate men may also be dangerous men!
Use this option to officially declare war on another clan. However, do not do so without first considering the consequences. Note that the check box asking allies to assist us defaults to yes.
Cavalry are not good at defending a static line. Don't put cavalry in a defensive line unless you're expecting to charge them out. If so, have infantry ready to plug the gap they leave behind.
A trade route has been opened between our lands and those of our new trading partner. Guard it well, as our enemies will attempt to raid it, potentially ruining the economy.

Light cavalry are an excellent choice for riding down light infantry and skirmishers. They often screen the main enemy force or harry isolated units, so getting rid of them is always a sound tactic, if you can catch them!
Attacking spear-equipped infantry in the flanks is a good way of taking them on with cavalry. You should always avoid charging onto sharp, pointy weapons that can be braced!

This panel shows you the information about an agent working for our clan. His name, position on the map, personality traits and skills relating to his military abilities are all listed, along with details of his retainers.
Outflanking is not the only way to get behind an enemy line. Find a weak spot, focus your missiles on it to weaken them and then punch through with your most offensive troops.
Placing cavalry units on your flanks gives you flexibility. They can counter any flanking move or make a move of their own if the way is clear.

This panel enables selection of the arts that, when mastered, will give us an advantage over our rivals. To begin, simply select the item you wish to master. There are no buildings required in order to do this, although there are some buildings that require mastery of certain arts before they can be constructed. Mouse over an art for a short description, details of effects and the length of time needed to master it. Further details are available in the encyclopaedia, accessed via the question mark button in the top right-hand corner of the panel.
Avoid charging your cavalry onto wooden stakes, as the weight and momentum of your horses mean they are unlikely to survive the encounter.
Battle statistics are displayed here, along with a breakdown of the condition of each surviving ship or unit. The button on the right-hand side breaks down the statistics to a "per unit" level.
Upgrading your rice paddies will create extra food each season, and keep your people fed. Select the improved irrigation building card to upgrade your rice paddies. Now end the turn.
An alliance with another clan could bring additional forces to bear against the Miyoshi. The Matsuda clan, your trading partners, may be interested.
Provoke a defending enemy into unwise attacks by enraging them. Light infantry and other skirmishers or missile cavalry are good troops to provoke this response.
Now Chosokabe Motochika is safe, move the camera to Tosa using the W, A, S and D keys.
To outflank the enemy, go around the ends of their line and attack their sides and rear. You will also need to engage their centre to hold them in place and stop them turning to face you.

Military access is a symbol of trust between two clans, and can be granted for a limited or indefinite time using the check boxes provided. Requests for access between allied clans are more likely to be approved.

A straight line of units is not always the best formation. A kink, vee or step will create a point in the line where two of your units can engage one of theirs. Exploit this, but remember it works both ways.

The naturally occurring resources or cultural buildings that are this provinces speciality are yet to be exploited to their full potential. Development of these sites can give bonuses to our clan in areas such as happiness, agent and unit experience, income, weapon accuracy, armour quality, etc.

Chosokabe Motochika's brother is now an adult, and is now a general in the Chosokabe forces. Generals lead armies: you do not have to risk the daimyo in battle. Armies with generals march further on the campaign map. Unfortunately, generals can be bribed. You can make them commissioners in the clan hierarchy to help their loyalty. They can also be assassinated by enemy agents.

Clicking on the assassinate button orders your agent to attempt to kill another agent upon arrival at their destination. As with all subterfuge actions there is a percentage chance of success, and failure may mean capture and execution.

The clan is bankrupt due to the high cost of maintaining our armies. All recruitment and construction has been halted until funds are available. May I respectfully suggest that we could reduce upkeep costs by disbanding some of our units?

Generals can use their rally ability to raise the morale of any unit and try to stop routing troops running from the field - except those in a shattered state, who will always ignore the call to rally. Once activated, the cursor can be placed anywhere within the radius of the selected general's influence.

Master, our large empire has many provinces to administer and there is barely enough money being made to cover our costs, as it has grown faster than we can tax it. We can make sure we collect tax in our provinces effectively by ensuring castles are upgraded to the highest available levels. This will increase repression sufficiently to enable tax increases whilst minimising the subsequent unrest.

Grab the enemy by the throat and then hit them in the vitals! It is the most basic strategy and is always valid. Have one part of your army hold the enemy in place while the rest manoeuvre to kill them.
There is more to life than battle and death. Mastery of the arts will help your quest for glory. Select the arts button in the bottom right-hand corner of the screen.

Some units are masters of concealment and can make themselves almost invisible in any terrain. Try putting these troops off to the side of your main force, where the enemy may well not notice them. A surprise flank attack can then be launched once the battle has begun.

advice_levels.advice_item_title: Allied, Neutral or Enemy Character Details
advice_levels.onscreen_text: This panel shows you information about an allied, neutral or enemy character. His name, position in the clan, personality traits and skills are all listed, along with details of his retainers and the effects all these elements have on his performance.

This panel gives information about how an art's effects are applied in the game, along with a detailed description of its function. Some arts are essential for constructing certain buildings, so it's worth reading all the information here and checking the encyclopaedia.
Wherever possible fight downhill. Whoever is higher has a great advantage.

Generals deploy their forces according to rank. A higher ranking general deploys after lower ranking ones, giving him the ability to view the deployment of a lower ranking opponent before committing his own troops.

Grouped units or ships can be set to one of several fixed group formations. Select a formation from the options on the left. Move your mouse over each formation to see what it does. Clicking on this button again will dismiss the formations menu.

Armies that are not large enough to be effective could be destroyed if attacked by a superior force, so it is prudent to merge any fragments together. Select one and right-click on another to walk to and merge with it.
As Awaji is now under your control, you can recruit warrior monk units and monk agents at the temples.

When in skirmish mode, troops avoid getting into melee by keeping their distance from the enemy. Not all troops are trained for this though. When a unit of missile troops is selected the skirmish mode button will appear in the bottom left-hand corner of the screen, where it can be toggled on or off.
When targeting men with missiles, pick out the enemy's best units. They die just as easily as the rabble.

Winning a battle isn't just about greater numbers - the balance of units and the general's ability are essential too. Look at the strength ratio and reinforcement information before committing the clan to fight, but beware - if we are attacked it may not be possible to avoid combat! The buttons at the bottom of this panel represent our battle options. Mouse over them to see what each one does.

Every army, fleet or agent can reveal information about rival armies, navies and castle towns in their immediate proximity or within their line of sight. The level of detail available depends on the type of character who is spying, so, for instance, ninja are able to reveal more than monks or missionaries.

A character's retainers consists of the objects, assistants and general hangers-on that great men accumulate during their careers. Characters will from time to time increase their retainers by choosing from a pool of available items and people, the presence of which will affect their abilities.

Master, we are not making enough of the trade infrastructure in this province. If we upgrade ports and province speciality buildings we allow a greater volume of trade to occur. In some cases it will be necessary to master certain arts or acquire certain resources before this can happen. Select the castle town of the province in question and mouse over the icon in the top right-corner of the building card to see what is required. Arts can be mastered through the button in the bottom right-hand corner of the campaign map. If a required resource is missing we must capture a province that contains it.

Group selected units or ships together by clicking on this button. Groups are useful for giving identical orders with a single command. You can reselect the group by clicking on its numbered tab, or by pressing the corresponding number key. Press this button again to dissolve the group.
The balance of power bar tracks the relative strength of our force against that of our enemy.

This panel is used to manually merge armies or fleets in order to assemble the strongest possible force. Click on the unit or ship you wish to move, then click on the central button to move it from one force to another. It is possible to select several units or ships at a time.
Mines facilitate the harvesting of underground resources such as gold and iron for trade and weapon-making purposes.
When outnumbered, make sure you keep the option of withdrawing open. This will help you to reduce casualties if the battle is being lost.
Cavalry troops make an excellent flanking force. They can move fast around the edge of the enemy formation and strike the sides or rear, but a clever opponent will be ready for this.
Rebellions grow in strength over time the more they are left unchecked. We must always act quickly in these instances, lord, otherwise the swinish rebels may capture a province!
Master, one of our sea trade routes is under attack from an enemy fleet! Without intervention they will continue to raid and take our goods and income for themselves.

In the unlikely event that our forces must retreat there is value in leaving a trail of destruction in our wake, so that nothing of value to the conqueror remains. Destroying buildings as they are abandoned ensures the enemy's hard-won prize is entirely worthless.
Deploying on a hill is always a good idea. Being uphill gives your troops a melee advantage, and climbing it will tire the enemy. Shooting downhill helps too.
A unit of your troops has been surrounded. As there is nowhere to run to they will now fight to the death! If your men manage to break through the enemy they will rout from the field.

Right-click to move our army to any part of the highlighted area. We can attack by right-clicking on a rival's army or castle town. Merge with a friendly army by moving to the same spot. Board a fleet at a coast by right-clicking to move onto it.

Useful natural resources are present in many provinces. Their exploitation increases the income available to the clan through trade, and in some cases improves the quality of weapons and armour that can be produced. Build or improve farms, mines and province speciality buildings to get the most from the available resources.

Attrition is the loss of men due to desertion, disease, etc. A unit will suffer attrition if it ends turn away from a castle town during the winter months. Ships are not designed as ocean-going vessels, so ship crews and armies transported by sea will suffer attrition if kept away from the coastline.
The finance panel gathers together essential economic and financial information about our clan.

Your general has the ability to raise the morale of nearby troops from his own army, although not those of any allies present. If placed near a unit that is wavering his presence may give his men the resolve they need to stay in the fight. The greater the general's command attribute, the more likely he is to prevent a rout.
At any time during a conflict, this option can be used to request that an ally joins a war that we are fighting. This means we can look for new allies to help if the conflict is not going our way.

In order to gain control of a garrisoned and fortified castle town it is often necessary to lay siege. During a siege your troops surround the castle town, either attempting to starve the defenders into capitulation or launching a direct assault.
You should make the Kono suffer for their insolence! Click on the "declare war" option.

The best naval commanders adapt their tactics to their environment. Take advantage of fog or heavy smoke to hide small or heavily damaged ships. This makes the enemy's job more difficult, a factor which can often prove crucial in the course of a battle.
There is often an advantage in ordering your infantry to counter-charge an attacking formation. The trick is to leave it until the last moment, so your own lines are not broken.
Press the Ctrl + S keys simultaneously to quickly save the game from the campaign map. Press Ctrl + L to quickly load the last save.
When attacking an enemy that refuses to move, sit back and shoot at them if you can. Even if they have missile superiority it may be worth the cost.
The presence of your general in proximity to his men has a morale-boosting influence on them.

In addition to skills gained through experience, characters within the clan will develop personality traits that affect their abilities. Some traits are present from the beginning, others are acquired as a character progresses through the campaign.
The best way to avoid being flanked is to stop the enemy flanking force from arriving. Cavalry are useful for this, so always deploy them on your flanks.
Use small mobile forces as bait for ambushes. Leave them looking vulnerable in plain view, with your main ambushing force hidden nearby.

Your ninja cannot fight an entire army, but he can strike a lethal blow. Select the sabotage army option. The ninja will poison their water and food: this will cause some casualties, and limit the army's movement.
The game is currently matching you with an on-line opponent. This will take a few moments. If at any time you change your mind, just click the cancel button to return to the pre-battle panel.

Before you fight a battle, assess the size and strength of each force. It may be wise for you to command your army in battle. You can also automatically and quickly resolve the fight. Choose an option now.
Be wary when attacking an enemy with their backs to the hills. Expect them to withdraw to the high ground.
If you're going to make a flanking move, try to pick a route where your force won't be visible for as long as possible - behind a hill, or behind or through woods.
Troops can be stationed inside a castle town to defend it in the event of an attack. Whilst there they will also act as a deterrent on any rebellious tendencies amongst the population.
Hills are good defensive positions, as being higher up a slope gives a large advantage in combat. Aim to fight the enemy on the steepest slope, not on the flatter top of the hill.

Income is dependent on the market value of the goods produced, which is in turn dependent on supply and demand across all clans and foreign trade partners. For up-to-date information, check the trade tab on the finance panel.

Infantry make a good fixing force to hold the enemy in place while cavalry outflank and kill, but any combination of cavalry, infantry and missile troops can be made to work as fixing and killing forces.

A very large army or fleet spread over two or more unit stacks may not be able to fight as a single force. A clan can field a maximum of twenty units at one time. In this instance, additional units will arrive for battle piecemeal, joining the fray to replace units that have been routed or destroyed. Siege weapons cannot be used as reinforcements as they are fixed in position during the deployment phase, so are therefore unable to move onto the battlefield once this phase is over.
A closely-packed mass of troops is a superb target for missile units on the battlefield. Keep pounding them and they'll take casualties!
You have just selected a character belonging to another clan, master. You cannot order it to do anything. Please select one of your own in order to learn more about their abilities.
Holding some cavalry in reserve at the centre gives you flexibility. As the battle takes shape you can move them quickly to where they are needed.
Ordering the whole army to attack throws away any chance of gaining an advantage. Even if you have enough brute force to win, you will have lost many more men than you needed to.

The review panel contains the unit or ship cards representing your force. Clicking on a card selects a unit or ship, double-clicking on it zooms the camera directly to it. Pausing the game then right-clicking on a card opens an information panel.

Remember that the goal here is to capture the castle, not destroy it! To achieve victory, either kill or rout the entire army, or capture the central keep. Before you begin, ensure that any siege weapons are positioned close enough to target the enemy and their defences.
Be wary of firing on the enemy when your own units are engaged in melee with them, you risk wiping out your own men as well!

You have selected a target outside the highlighted area. This means the character cannot reach his target this season. Provided that an enemy does not block his path, he will continue on his journey during the next season.

This option is used to broker trade agreements. Once agreed, a trade route is opened between our clan and the territory of our trade partners, enabling goods to be traded for mutual advantage and profit.
Taxes are set at a clan-wide level, not by individual province. Keeping taxes at high levels for protracted lengths of time makes people unhappy and reduces future economic growth.

Up to four camera bookmarks can be set up to navigate between points on the campaign map. Place the cursor in the desired place and press Shift + F9, F10, F11, or F12 to set a bookmark. Simply press the relevant F key to view a bookmark. Bookmarks cannot be deleted, only overwritten with new ones.
Funds are deducted from our treasury at the beginning of each turn to pay for the supplies and wages of the clan's troops. This is known as unit upkeep.

We have recruited so many units the treasury is buckling under the weight of their upkeep. Capturing new provinces would spread the cost, as well as putting our soldiers to good use! Raising taxes will also help, although that also increases the chances of insurrection amongst the people.

When viewing user interface panels you will notice a question mark button in their top right-hand corners. This is the help button, click on it to open the relevant page of the encyclopaedia for an in-depth explanation of the panel's functionality.

Clicking on the sabotage button means your ninja will attempt to damage a building upon arrival at his destination. As with all subterfuge actions there is a percentage chance of success, and failure may mean capture and execution.

Master we are bankrupt! There is no money left in the treasury, but there are several things that can be done to reverse our misfortune - raise taxes if possible, establish further trade agreements and trade routes, or disband unused units.

Buildings that have been damaged due to sabotage or battle can be rebuilt. To repair a building, select it and click on the rebuild button to the left of the review panel. If simply left, damaged buildings will be automatically repaired very slowly over time at no cost.
Running everywhere with your cavalry lets them cover ground quickly, but they will get tired if you overdo it. Tired troops are less effective in combat.

An army that has been stationary for a turn is "dug in". This means they will have had time to prepare and deploy defences on the field if attacked. If the army is moved at any point it will no longer be dug in if attacked during the same season.

Obedience to the rule of the daimyo is measured in public order. If unhappiness begins to outweigh happiness and repression at any point then the resultant unrest can lead to rebellion, if left unchecked. Keep taxes at reasonable levels, maintain sufficient food levels and ensure that castle towns are garrisoned to stop public order bubbling over into insurrection.
All armies and fleets have a zone of control, represented by the circle displayed around them. You cannot enter a zone of control unless you are attacking the army within it.

Before starting another war, improving your castle would be wise. You can add to its unit capacity, gain income and develop the province. Select Iyo, then click the construction tab's stronghold building card.

There are many new arts to be mastered that will assist our clan in its bid for supremacy. To select one, open the mastery of the arts panel by clicking on the dedicated button in the bottom right-hand corner of the screen.

Making a trade agreement with another clan automatically opens a sea trade route between us. Our routes are displayed yellow, those of neutral clans are white, and those belonging to enemies are red. Those trade routes that are shared with an enemy clan are yellow. Make a trade agreement by entering into diplomacy.
If the enemy is forming for an attack, it's often a good idea to let them come forward and tire themselves through marching.
Extremes of heat or cold will give a fatigue penalty to units not used to living and fighting in such conditions. Some units are naturally resistant to this penalty.
When the enemy have a lot of fast, light troops or cavalry, consider moving your light infantry and skirmishers closer to other supporting units, so they don't get caught in the open.

The order in which reinforcements take to the battlefield can be determined by left-clicking and dragging units into the order of your choice - the unit on the far left being the first to take the field.

Ninja can sabotage a rival army, affecting their ability to move during a turn and causing casualties by poisoning their food and water supplies. Right-click on a rival army and select the army sabotage option to undermine their movements.

Welcome to the Sengoku Jidai, "the age of the country at war". This is Shikoku island, far from Kyoto and the Emperor. Following the death of his father, Chosokabe Motochika is now the clan daimyo. Select him now.
Now return the daimyo to safety. With Motochika selected, right-click on Tosa, the nearby castle town.
These are the units you can recruit: mouse over the unit cards to see more details about each one before you pay to recruit them. Now, select a yari ashigaru unit.
Armies are not the only way to beat an enemy. Cunning can be a weapon too. Iyo has a sake den; on the recruitment tab click on the ninja button and hire one of these killers.
Now select the province panel recruitment tab.

Generals can inspire a single unit to increase the violence of their melee attack, improves reload rate and rate of fire, and ensures the unit's morale does not break for the duration of the effect. Select your general and then right-click on a unit. If the unit is not standing within the radius of his influence, your general will move closer until it is. Once targeted, the unit will be inspired for a short time before the ability burns out.

A trade post is the means through which you can obtain special resources from distant foreign powers who do not otherwise appear in the game. Trade posts are positioned out to sea away from the coastline of Japan. In order to begin this trade, build a trade ship and send it to a trade post icon by right-clicking on it. Trading commences when your trade vessel's flag flashes with the yellow coin graphic. If all resources have been exported the maximum value of the trade route will be shown.

A drop-in battle is a feature allowing a human opponent to take the place of the AI clan in a campaign battle or fight a battle in another's campaign in place of the AI. This is achieved via the on-line battle mechanism. If you checked the enable drop-in battles checkbox when setting up your campaign, you will occasionally receive an invitation to fight another player in a battle from their campaign. If accepted, your current campaign progress will be saved before you join them on the battlefield. Once the battle is over, the campaign automatically resumes where it was left off.

All male family members automatically become generals as soon as they come of age. In addition, new generals will be periodically offered for adoption into your clan as individuals distinguish themselves in battle or volunteer to lead your armies.

This clan has now become our vassal. Vassals can take advantage of the military might of their overlord in exchange for 50% of their income and unlimited military access, as well as counting towards their overlords victory conditions. They may find themselves dragged into a conflict not of their own design, and unlike a regular ally cannot decline a request to fight for their overlord without automatically declaring war on them.

Attrition is the loss of men due to desertion, disease, etc. An army will suffer attrition if it ends the season away from a castle town during the winter months. Ships are not designed as ocean-going vessels, so ship crews and armies transported by sea will suffer attrition if kept away from the coastline.

Master, our clan could be making more money through trade. We should instigate diplomacy to make new trade agreements. The diplomatic negotiations panel can be accessed through the button in the bottom right-hand corner of the screen.

Naval battles are frequently a series of individual duels between ships, but there is value in maintaining formation and contact with the general for as long as possible. The morale-boosting effect of being close to the flagship can be passed from ship to ship, as long as they are within hailing distance of each other.
Avoid approaching places surrounded by heights, where troops can be entrapped and cut off, or where the land is sunken. Keep your distance and draw the enemy towards these areas.
Attacking infantry from behind is the single best way to kill them with cavalry, but always keep an eye out for enemy troops supporting them!

A flanking force of cavalry can be a serious threat to the enemy, but a mixed force of cavalry and infantry, although slower, is more dangerous. Your infantry can engage theirs, leaving your cavalry free to kill.
Light infantry carry wooden stakes to deter the attentions of enemy cavalry. Deploy them at any time using the dedicated button on the battle control panel.
Rather than racing the enemy to get control of high ground, try to approach it out of sight so they see no reason to hurry, while distracting them with bait they cannot resist.
When forced to fight in mountain passes stay close to the valley walls. You may be able to take advantage of the slopes, or at least use them to protect one flank.

When a drop-in battle is possible, there will be a button to select this mode on the pre-battle panel. Clicking this will request a human opponent, display information about the connection, and estimate the amount of time it will take to be matched up. Click on the cancel button at any time to return to the pre-battle panel.

If a castle or army is attacked from the sea, the defender can choose to intercept the invading army and fight. If this does not happen, the invaders immediately lay siege to the castle town. The defenders will flee to safety outside the attacker's zone of control.

Outflanking forces can be turned into fixing forces. If you commit a large outflanking force and do not attack from the front, the enemy will be forced to turn and face you, presenting his flanks to what was your centre.

A blockade is a cordon of ships that prevents any trade going through a port whilst it is in place and any fleet moored there from escaping without fighting a battle. It can be broken by an attack on the blockading fleet. You can blockade a port by right-clicking on it as you would another fleet. If there is an enemy fleet inside, a cordon graphic will appear to indicate a blockade is under way. Otherwise, your fleet will sail straight into the port and occupy it.
Use the space bar to speed up the movement of all characters, armies or fleets on the campaign map. Press the space bar again to slow them down again.

As a unit fights and survives battles, it gains experience that improves its ability to deal with future combat situations. Amongst other things, experience increases morale, so an experienced unit is less likely to break and run from battle when under stress and fatigue. See the encyclopaedia for more information.
Pressing the melee button locks the selected melee-capable units into melee mode. All attack orders will result in a hand-to-hand attack until you click on the melee button again.
If an infantry unit is about to be charged by cavalry, make sure it is stationary. That way, the men can brace themselves against the impact and will take fewer losses.
Try to keep some forces in reserve behind the front line. They can fill any gaps that develop and turn to deal with threats to either flank.
The yari ashigaru are now in the recruitment queue. The cost has been taken from your treasury. These spearmen will be ready in just one turn: this is the number on the unit card.
Tire your enemy out by keeping them constantly occupied. Make them rush about by offering some advantage, for example by moving fast light troops into a vulnerable position.
Your agent has news: there is a quarry inside Sanuki province. It is very valuable and produces the stone needed for mighty castles.

An ungarrisoned castle town automatically generates units of samurai retainers and women to defend it if attacked. Although not as effective during a battle as regular troops, and unable to leave the castle town in which they were spawned, they are well able to manage day to day public order problems.

There are three ways to move an army from a castle town onto the landscape. In order to move the entire force select the castle town and right-click on the point you wish to move to, to move a specific unit select it and right-click on the point you wish to move to, or left-click on it and drag it out onto the map. When you release the cursor the army will walk to the chosen spot. Ctrl and left-click enables you to select more than one unit at once.

This tab lists all the provinces currently controlled by our clan by name, public order, speciality, food and wealth. It can be sorted by each of those headings. It also shows information about those provinces adjacent to our own so we can make informed decisions regarding future conquests.

We can call a clan to war whenever diplomatic negotiations are taking place between two allies, or when an alliance is proposed between two clans and our own is at war with one that our proposed ally is not. Note that a refusal to provide support for an existing conflict does not break an alliance, but there is a diplomatic relations penalty for doing so.

Master, there are roads within our territory that could be upgraded further, which would increase the distance we can see into neighbouring provinces and speed up unit replenishment. Upgrading roads also improves the quality of their surfaces, thereby enabling an army to march faster along them.
When attacking an enemy that is deployed on a hill, attack up the most gentle slope, even if it takes a while to get there. Fewer troops will be exhausted by the time they reach the top of the slope.
The clan management panel gathers together the essential statistics and information used to manage our clan's hierarchy.
Attacking spear-equipped infantry from the front is a good way to kill off your cavalry units. Attack from the flank or rear - or better still, use infantry!
Once the Kono's castle is in sight, select your army and right-click on the castle to begin the siege.

The delay phase allows you to use the weather to your advantage by picking the optimum conditions for your units to fight in. For instance, if the enemy have a lot of missile weapons fighting in the rain will reduce their effectiveness.
Ports, farms and speciality buildings are positioned away from the castle town, so careful strategic planning and garrisoning is required in order to adequately defend our assets.

The withdraw button causes a unit or ship to leave the battle by travelling toward the edge of the field by the shortest route. It can be called back at any stage before it leaves by issuing a move or attack order.

It is possible to take a castle town without risking a pitched battle. A patient general can throttle the fight out of the defenders by laying siege for several seasons. This is time-consuming, but eventually hunger or an angry populace will force a surrender.

We are successfully blockading an enemy port. This does not affect their ability to build new ships or repair existing combat-damaged ships, but all trade income through it will be suspended for the life of the blockade.
Terrain has an effect on a unit's movement speed. Sticking to roads or short grass will ensure your units move at maximum speed.
Metsuke are recruited at market buildings. Awa has one; you may recruit a metsuke there.

Details of victory conditions and missions are stored here. In addition to becoming Shogun, each clan has a set of predetermined territorial conquests that it must complete in order to attain victory. These are displayed at the top of this tab. Click on a mission to check the time remaining for completion or read its details again.
Don't start your attack by engaging the enemy's elite troops. In a perfect battle you would rout their army without fighting their best units at all.
Cavalry cause extra casualties when first charging in due to the impetus of their attack. A cycle of charge, withdraw, charge causes maximum casualties for minimum losses. Repeat until done.
You can judge the progress of a boarding action with the boarding action meter that appears above the ships involved.

Use ninja to damage enemy buildings through acts of sabotage. Right-click on a castle town and select a building to sabotage from the list or, alternatively, any building elsewhere in the province. Your ninja will then move there and attempt to damage it upon his arrival.

This tab shows all the units or ships available for recruitment from the building you have currently selected. Right-click on the ship or ship card to see its description. Left-click on it to add it to the queue, and again to remove it. Recruitment cost is displayed underneath, recruitment time is shown in the top left-hand corner of the card.

Your archery dojo is now complete. In Japan, the Chosokabe are rightly renowned as archers, and highly skilled units are now available. Recruit a unit of bow samurai for your army. They will add to your strength!

To disembark an army or character onto land select it and hover your mouse over the coast. The cursor will change into an arrow with a figure - illustrating that the army or character can be disembarked. Right-click to disembark. Disembarkation also works by left-clicking and dragging the army or character onto the land. Press the Ctrl + A keys to select all units or agents on a tab.

Send multiple trade ships to a trade post for an increased share of the goods, or raid enemy trade routes to keep the income from reaching its wrongful destination! Remember though that attacking trade is an act of war!
This piece cannot move any further now. It will be available again next season.

Fleets that are not large enough to be effective could be destroyed if attacked by a superior force, so it is prudent to merge any fragments together. Select one and right-click on another to row to and merge with it.

The game speed controls are used to adjust the speed of the battle. You can pause the game or put it into slow motion by clicking on buttons to the left or return it to normal by clicking on the central button again. The two positions further right are for double and quadruple speed respectively.
When assaulting a castle, many troop types can scale enemy walls. Select a unit, then right-click on a section of wall to order the troops to climb the wall.

Master, we are losing money hand over fist, very soon there will be no money left in our treasury! There are several things that can be done to reverse this alarming state of affairs - raise taxes if possible or upgrade the castle to ensure maximum efficiency in tax collection, establish further trade agreements and trade routes, or disband unused units.

Long-standing trade partners develop a healthy respect for each other, reflected by a gradual improvement in diplomatic relations and increased income from trade routes over the life of the agreement.
Your magnificent stronghold is done! Enemies will tremble when they set eyes upon it! Now the castle has another site for buildings. Construct a dojo to recruit more samurai units.
Light cavalry beat light troops and heavy cavalry beat light cavalry. All cavalry are vulnerable to spears. Try to match your cavalry to the right target.
It is possible to cycle back through advice that has already been displayed by use of the back button on this user interface.
We can use this option to demand a clan places a trade embargo on another. An embargo cancels all trade between the target clan and those placing it until lifted.

Noble lord, our army has suffered casualties and requires fresh recruits to replenish troop numbers. If an army contains a general and is in a friendly province, unit replenishment will occur automatically. Without a general, an army can only replenish within a castle town belonging to its own clan. The closer an army is to a province with fresh recruits in it, the faster the rate of replenishment will be. If no replenishment occurs it may be because the army is in an enemy province or an area of attrition.
The riot in this province has grown into an armed rebellion! There is no time to negotiate a peaceful solution now - we must send troops in at once to defeat the rebels!

Master, there is a degree of unrest in this province as the majority of the population follow a different religion to that of their rulers. Send missionaries to proselytise the true religion to the masses.

This tab shows all fleets currently owned by our clan, their available movement points, current position, the commanding general's name and loyalty, and ship numbers. It can be sorted by each of those headings.
Diplomatic options are shown on the left. Select "request trade agreement". A trade agreement increases your wealth each season and lets you share resources with your trading partner.

During the deployment phase you can secretly arrange our units inside the deployment zone before battle commences. The enemy general will deploy his men within the opposite area. The attacker always deploys first. When you are ready to fight click on the gong button.

Repression is the enforcement of your rule by the presence of garrison troops. The grey pips in the public order section of this panel represent repression through intimidation from garrisoned units. Whilst it is useful to keep the population in order, rebellion following a period of heavy repression can be difficult to suppress.

This option demands that a clan become our vassals. Vassal clans can take advantage of the military might of their overlord in exchange for 50% of their income and unlimited military access. However, unlike a regular ally, a vassal cannot decline a request to fight for their overlord, they can reassert their independence only by declaring war on them.

This panel shows you information about a general working for our clan. His name, age, rank, personality traits and military skills are all listed, along with details of his retainers and a breakdown of his command abilities. You can also access the skill tree via the dedicated button in the top right-hand side of the panel.

Cannon and other siege weapons can be a great incentive for a defending enemy on hilly terrain not to just sit there and wait for you. You can bombard them until they move to a more suitable place to die.
A Sogo army is near your border. Select your ninja and right click on the army.

Master! Rioting has broken out in this province as the peasants are very unhappy. We could appease the rioters by lowering taxes or send soldiers in to put them down. Whatever we decide, we must act quickly before the riot becomes a rebellion!
This screen allows you to search for a drop-in battle on-line and replace the AI clan in that battle. If one is available you will be connected to it as soon as is possible.
We have successfully raided the enemy's trade along this route. Their income is reduced and the goods are added to our own supply.
These developments will take several turns to finish. Meanwhile, you could bolster your forces or improve roads and farms in your lands. I will advise again when the stronghold is completed.

Chosokabe Motochika's honour and fame are increased by capturing Iyo province. Honour increases the loyalty of generals and aids the clan's diplomatic efforts. Fame makes the Emperor and other clans notice the Chosokabe. Click on the clan button to see its current status.
Most excellent! The Sogo army will not threaten your borders for another season. If your ninja targets other armies, castle towns and agents he will have other subterfuge options.
The ships you can construct are displayed here. Mouse over the ship cards for more details before you spend any money building one. For now, select the bow kobaya ship card.

Ah, victory! And with a purpose: your trade route is secure. After winning the battle, there is a chance you captured an enemy ship. Captured ships are shown on the battle statistics panel, but remember you have to pay their upkeep costs from now on!

Metsuke are your secret police. They can detect ninja and dispatch them with ruthless efficiency. They also ensure loyalty, obedience and keep order among your people. Metsuke are not spies but they can still provide information about enemy agents, armies, and buildings.

Some clans need convincing before they will accept a diplomatic deal. Marriage can be used to strengthen ties between two clans, if you have an available daughter. You can also offer a hostage as part of an agreement. Only children can be used as hostages.

Monks convert others to Buddhism, inspire armies and pacify the people. They can also demoralise an enemy army, convert metsuke and persuade them to retire, incite revolts or reduce the chance of bribery. A monk automatically increases Buddhist faith in a province and spies on your rivals.

Hmmm. The Miyoshi trade routes are now vulnerable. Your fleet could get rich pickings! Select your fleet and right click on the Miyoshi trade route. Raiding like this will give you some of their trade income and hurt them!

Excellent! Just like recruitment, construction takes time, but the archery dojo is being built. The cost has been taken from your treasury. You can get the money back: left-click on the building card to cancel the work. For now, click on the end turn button until the dojo is finished.

During your campaign your clan will face many difficult dilemmas. These can have all kinds of consequences for your people, depending on your decision. So: be careful, as you will not face a dilemma twice. The results of a dilemma are usually temporary, but consider them when deciding.

The Chosokabe clan grows stronger. It is time to send a mighty army to seize Awa province from the Miyoshi clan. Shikoku island will be yours! You may find cavalry useful now; the stables in Sanuki let you recruit cavalry units.

In order to construct a proposal, select a clan from the central section and then diplomatic options from the left-hand side of the screen. The proposed deal will take shape under the heading "your offers". Click on an option to remove it from the deal and use the clear offer button if you want to start afresh. When ready, click on the propose offer button. If you decide not to negotiate further use the end negotiations button to cancel diplomacy. Remember that a proposal involving too many elements may be rejected out of hand.
The map displays the diplomatic relationship between the selected clan and other clans, ranging from friendly - shown in green, to hostile - shown in red.

Entering into diplomacy gives the clan a means to negotiate matters of alliance, war and trade. To begin negotiations with another clan, select one from the drop-down list attached to the radar map and double-click on it. Alternatively, click on the diplomacy button in the bottom right-hand side of the screen and then select a clan from there.

Click on any area of the radar map to snap directly to that area. The + and - buttons enable the map to be zoomed in or out. Lists of our clan's current armies, fleets, agents, provinces, neighbouring clans, as well as important messages and events, current missions and victory conditions can be viewed by clicking on the buttons at the bottom of the radar map.
The family & council tab displays information about members of the daimyo's family. Use this panel to nominate his heir and appoint generals to military and civic commissioner roles.

The summary tab is used to display important information about the state of our clan, such as bonus effects and clan fame, in one place for ease of reference. Mouse over them to reveal further details.

The taxes tab shows a summary of our projected income, maps the effect that tax has on public order and allows the adjustment of taxation levels for every province under our control. From here, AI management of taxation and construction can be specified. Click on the button at the bottom of the panel to go straight to the province with the lowest public order. In most cases, adjusting the tax levels should fix the problem.

The trade tab details the current prices of all resources produced across our territory and shows how these are exported to our trade partners - together with the profit made from exporting to each one. Also shown are the resources we produce, those we have gained from our trade partners or those we are yet to acquire. Certain advanced units and buildings require access to these resources before they can be recruited or constructed.
This tab gathers together all reports, summaries and notices relevant to our clan. Click on one to see the message or report. When an important event occurs the panel will open automatically.
Ports do not just facilitate trade income, they also enable the construction of naval vessels. Note that ships can also be ordered directly from fleets if commanded by a general.
In readiness for a siege assault, a ninja can infiltrate an enemy castle and sabotage the gates. If he is successful the gates will be open when we reach the battlefield.

The ninja acts as an assassin, spy, saboteur and scout, and is recruited via the stealth building chain. In addition to their subterfuge skills, ninja also increase the movement and line of sight of our armies when placed inside them. They can also establish spy networks within our castle towns, which in turn increase a province's line of sight. Ninja are invisible to the enemy until detected. They are vulnerable to detection by metsuke and exceptionally dangerous to monks and missionaries.
Geisha are specialised, expert assassins. Although more effective than ninja at carrying out assassinations, geisha are always visible to the enemy, making them susceptible to capture by metsuke.

Rival agents can be removed by assassination. Select a target for your geisha to kill. Decide if the chance of success is worth the risk before confirming the order, as failure may mean capture and execution.

The metsuke are our secret policemen, recruited through the market building chain. Metsuke ensure loyalty and obedience from friendly generals, increase income by preventing corruption, and keep our castle towns and armies safe from enemy subterfuge when positioned inside them. Metsuke can also bribe enemy garrisons, generals and armies, and detect and apprehend enemy agents in our territory. They are vulnerable to conversion by enemy monks or missionaries and are exceptionally dangerous to ninja.

Metsuke can bribe a general or the garrison of a castle town to switch allegiance to our clan. If successful, there is a chance that one or more of his units will follow him, also changing sides. Bribing a neutral army anywhere is tantamount to a declaration of war against their clan. Following a successful bribe, an army on neutral or friendly territory will retreat to our territory unless we have a diplomatic agreement for military access in place.
The presence of metsuke within an army or castle town will increase the chances of detecting enemy ninja and reduce the chances that they will succeed in their dishonourable task.
Metsuke can detect and apprehend enemy agents. Success will lead to their imprisonment or execution.

The presence of a ninja within an army will increase the distance they are able to see and travel within a season, and decrease the chances that a monk or missionary will succeed in demoralising them.

The placement of a ninja inside one of our castle towns will enable him to set up a spy network there. This not only increases line of sight from the province, it also makes it easier to detect hidden agents and armies, and decreases the chance that a monk or missionary will be successful in encouraging a revolt.

Our armies cannot enter the ports or any buildings outside of a castle town; either our own, those of our allies or those belonging to the enemy. These buildings can, however, be protected if they fall within the zone of control of one of our armies. Enemy castle towns and ports can be raided by armies in the same way as trade routes; simply select an army and right-click on the target to attack.

Monks can convert others to Buddhism, inspire a friendly army or pacify an angry populace with their enlightened rhetoric, and, by the same token, demoralise an enemy force, reduce the chances of successful bribery, convert metsuke and cause them to retire, or incite an enemy population to revolt. Monks are recruited via the Buddhist chain of buildings. The trusting nature of this man makes him highly susceptible to assassination by ninja or geisha.

Missionaries can convert others to Christianity, inspire a friendly army or pacify an angry populace, and, by the same token, demoralise an enemy force, reduce the chances of successful bribery, convert metsuke and cause them to retire, or incite an enemy population to revolt. Missionaries are recruited via the Christian chain of buildings. The trusting nature of this man makes him highly susceptible to assassination by ninja or geisha.

Agents are recruited directly from a province via the recruitment tab on the review panel. Recruitment is instant, but cost may vary depending on a number of factors, such as the presence of certain buildings, clan or character traits.

Each general has a loyalty rating that is used to determine his likeliness to be bribed, leave our clan and defect to another. Loyalty is influenced by factors such as the daimyo's honour, glorious victories in battle, marriage within the clan, being made heir to the clan leadership, the acquisition of character traits and skills, the choices made during dilemmas and whether a general is made a commissioner or neglected within the clan. If their loyalty gets too low there may be no choice other than to order that they commit seppuku.
You have been wise. The consequences of your choice are at the top of the screen, to the left of the radar map.
They can use persuasion and bribery when catching enemy agents and make generals, armies, and castle towns change allegiance. Keep this in mind when sending out your metsuke.
There is a degree of unrest in this province as the majority of the population follow a different religion to the one you have chosen, master. Send monks to spread enlightenment to the people.

Your stables can only provide light cavalry, but if Awa province is taken, the best warhorses on Shikoku will be yours. Your cavalry will then become truly formidable! Even the bravest men will quail as they charge!
This province is becoming poorer and poorer. We must reduce the tax burden here, master - lest the peasants starve!

As generals within the clan acquire experience points there will be the opportunity to select useful skills from the skill tree. This can be accessed through the button on the top right of the character's details panel, accessed by right-clicking on his portrait. The tree enables you to choose the elements that make up the general's skill set yourself.

As an alternative to straight-forward occupation, upon capture of a castle town there is also an option to loot it as well. Doing so will add a lump sum to our treasury, but there will be a greater public order penalty than that caused by occupation alone.

A clan can demonstrate its commitment to a diplomatic agreement by offering a hostage as a guarantee. Any one of the daimyo's children, though not one that is a general, can be sent to another clan for a period of eight seasons. If, at the end of this time, the deal has been honoured, the hostage will be returned. If the agreement is broken at any time the hostage will be killed.

Although marriages within our clan between daughters and retainers are possible, they are also a useful diplomatic tool when dealing with other clans. The offering of an unmarried daughters by one clan to another in order to seal good relations between the two can greatly strengthen a diplomatic relationship, and produce heirs to the leadership of the husband's clan. When a daughter is offered and accepted she is removed from our family tree and enters her husband's. Other clans may disapprove of the match, negatively affecting our relationship with them.

Commissioner positions can be allocated to both family and wider clan members, and are divided into military and civic positions. As well as improving the general's loyalty, each commission confers a bonus in the area of his expertise. For further details click on the question mark button to open the encyclopaedia.

If our daimyo is to become Shogun - military ruler of all Japan - we must defeat the current Shogunate, the Ashikaga clan, capturing and holding the capital of Kyoto for four seasons. At this point the Emperor will declare our clan leader Shogun. We can make a bid for the Shogunate at any time, although the current incumbent may pre-emptively attack us if we become too powerful. War with the Shogun for either reason may result in other clans declaring war on our own in support of the status quo.

An army transported by one of our fleets can launch an attack against an enemy force on the coast. Once the attack order has been given and the fleet has sailed to the coastline, our army will disembark and attack the enemy force. It is not possible for our force to withdraw from battle once this has occurred. Friendly armies aboard nearby ships cannot act as reinforcements. Only armies that have disembarked and are not already engaged in a coastal assault can reinforce them.

The enemy has launched a coastal assault against one of our armies in the field. If we accept, our force will move to engage the attackers. Refusal to take part in the battle will cause our force to retreat.

The enemy has launched a coastal assault against our army garrisoned inside the castle town. If we accept, our force will sally out to engage the attackers, but the enemy will automatically besiege the castle if we lose the battle. Refusal to take part in the battle will automatically result in the siege of the castle.

Monks can convert both the populations of provinces and other agents to their religion, although it is difficult for a monk to convert a missionary and vice versa. Conversion of a population to Buddhism takes place simply via a monk's presence in a province.

Missionaries can convert the populations of provinces and other agents to their religion, although it is more difficult for a missionary to convert a monk and vice versa. Conversion of a population to Christianity takes place simply by a missionary's presence in a province.

As agents within the clan acquire experience points there will be the opportunity to select useful skills from the skill tree. The tree will be displayed whenever a new level of experience has been reached, enabling you to choose the elements that make up the agent's skill set yourself.

When our clan reaches the top of a castle town-based building chain it may then be possible to construct a legendary building. We can only construct a particular legendary building once and they cannot be destroyed under any circumstances. If we are the first to construct a legendary building our clan will be awarded a permanent clan trait and its associated effects.

Now work has been completed on a legendary building it is possible to recruit heroes - exceptionally skilled proponents of the sword, spear, bow or naginata. The hero available depends on the type of legendary building constructed. Heroes are fielded and fight in exactly the same way as other units in our army, but carry additional bonuses reflecting their specialist weapon skills. Each unit contains the hero and his entourage, much like a general and his bodyguard.

Some events will present a dilemma. Dilemmas will open automatically and require a decision to be made before continuing. Choose carefully as the wrong decision may have serious consequences for the clan.
Details of the clan's financial status, including taxation and trade, are displayed on the finance panel - accessed via the finance button in the bottom right-hand corner of the screen.

The clan's family tree, details of the daimyo's heir and the offices of his councillors are displayed via the clan management panel - accessed via the dedicated button in the bottom right-hand corner of the screen.

Generals value military commissions more than civil ones, but both increase their loyalty. They also give useful bonuses: better unit replenishment, for example. Commissions are assigned by clicking the family and council tab.

The daimyo is the leader of our clan and also a fine general. He can be given command of an army and sent into battle the same way as any other general. This of course means he can also be killed, so be careful not to expose him to unnecessary risks on the battlefield.

Total War: Shogun 2 contains an encyclopaedia function containing detailed information about all aspects of the game, including units, buildings, arts and sections on how to play. It can be accessed at any time from the dedicated button in the top left-hand corner of the campaign map or battlefield, and via the question mark buttons in the top right-hand corner of most panels.

A character has gained experience and risen in rank. You may now select a skill for him. Right click on the character portrait to open the character details panel. Now click on the skill tree button in the top right corner.

Take time to explore the battle user interface. Press buttons and click on graphics for details of their function. Further information is available through tooltips when hovering over an item or from the encyclopaedia, accessed via the encyclopaedia button in the top left-hand corner of the screen.

Master, if I may be so bold - we are almost bankrupt. If we do not take measures to reduce our outgoings the treasury will be empty in five seasons. We must disband units, increase trade capacity or raise taxes to increase our income in the short term.

Every clan has a set of characteristics particular to them, known as clan traits. Clan traits work in a similar way to character traits but are present from the start of a campaign, rather than awarded as it progresses. Each trait has one or more effects that bestow a bonus or penalty on an aspect of the clan's activities, detailed by mousing over the icon next to the radar map or checking the summary tab on the clan management panel. Clan traits are always permanent.

The bonuses awarded from dilemma decisions, events, mission rewards and clan traits are displayed here. These may take the form of bonuses to income, construction and recruitment costs, clan honour, boosts to unit experience, etc. Some are permanent - as in the case of clan traits - others are temporary, lasting just a few turns.

From time to time, missions are issued either by our clan, the Shogun or, if appropriate, any European trade partners we may have. Mission objectives may be reviewed from the objectives list beneath the radar map or on the summary tab on the clan management panel. Although there is no penalty for failing, successful completion of a mission results in a reward, often in the form of bonus effects. If a mission becomes unachievable due to factors outside of our control it will be cancelled.

The threaten option is a diplomatic tool to help us get our own way in certain situations. The effectiveness of a threat greatly depends on the military strength of the clan we are threatening relative to our own, so we must not use the option without fully considering what it means to do so. Note that making empty threats will make future threats less effective.

Farms supply food and castle towns consume it. Although food is automatically distributed across all our provinces, if the total consumption in towns is not matched by farms then food shortages can occur, which will lead to unrest and, ultimately, rebellion. Make sure our farms are upgraded as we construct larger castle towns.

A character's retainers consists of the objects, assistants and general hangers-on that agents accumulate whilst completing their missions. Characters will from time to time increase their retainers by choosing from a pool of available items and people, the presence of which will affect their attributes.

In addition to skills gained through experience, characters within the clan will develop personality traits that affect their abilities. Some traits are present from the beginning, others are acquired as a character progresses through the campaign.

This is the character skill tree, where the experience gained by generals and agents during the campaign can be used to acquire useful skills. As a character improves, they gain experience points that gradually increase their ranking stars; each star being equivalent to two skill choices. Click on the question mark button for more information about skills in the encyclopaedia.

Some provinces contain resources or cultural specialities that enable the construction of special buildings, the type of which depends on the speciality of the province. They are constructed in exactly the same way as any other building, and confer special bonuses or provide key resources.
This tab lists the clans whose territory neighbours your own and information about the diplomatic relations between you.
So, the agreement is sealed. Next season will be prosperous! When ready, click on end turn.

Your trade agreement has attracted wolves, human wolves. The Miyoshi clan plan to raid your trade route! Piracy must be crushed so that trade reaches your ports. You have been given a fleet to counter this threat. Merge your new fleet and your bow ship into one force. Protect your trade route!
The new castle upgrade will increase the province's food requirements. More food will come from improving your rice paddies. Select one now.

The rumours were true: the island has a trading post! You have now acquired a trade ship. These create income by connecting the trade posts on remote islands to your trade ports. Select the trade ship, and right click on the trading post. The ship will start trade with your port.

Your bow koboya is complete. It would be wise to investigate Yashiro island: there are rumours of pirates and great riches there. Perhaps there is a trading post? Select the ship and right click near Yashiro to find out.
With a bow kobaya under construction you should end the turn and await its completion.
