Enemy settlements and ports can be raided by armies in the same way as trade routes; simply select an army and right-click on the target to attack.

Our territory has many provinces to administer and there is barely enough money being made to cover our costs, as it has grown faster than we can tax it. We can make sure we collect tax in our provinces effectively by ensuring settlements are upgraded to the highest available levels. This will increase repression sufficiently to enable tax increases whilst minimising the subsequent unrest.
Attrition is the loss of men due to desertion, disease, etc. An army will suffer attrition if it ends turn away from a settlement during the winter months.

This tab lists all the provinces currently controlled by our clan by name, public order, speciality, and wealth. It can be sorted by each of those headings. It also shows information about those provinces adjacent to our own so we can make informed decisions regarding future conquests.
Ports, farms and speciality buildings are positioned away from the settlement, so careful strategic planning and garrisoning is required in order to adequately defend our assets.

We are losing money hand over fist, very soon there will be no money left in our treasury! There are several things that can be done to reverse this alarming state of affairs - raise taxes if possible or upgrade the settlement to ensure maximum efficiency in tax collection, establish further trade agreements and trade routes, or disband unused units.

Our army has suffered casualties and requires fresh recruits to replenish troop numbers. If an army contains a general and is in a friendly province, unit replenishment will occur automatically. Without a general, an army can only replenish inside a settlement belonging to its own clan. The closer an army is to a province with fresh recruits in it, the faster the rate of replenishment will be. If no replenishment occurs it may be because the army is in an enemy province or an area of attrition.

The enemy has launched a coastal assault against our army garrisoned inside the settlement. If we accept, our force will sally out to engage the attackers, but the enemy will automatically besiege the settlement if we lose the battle. Refusal to take part in the battle will automatically result in a siege.

When our clan reaches the top of a settlement-based building chain it may then be possible to construct a legendary building. A particular legendary building can only be constructed once and cannot be destroyed under any circumstances. If we are the first to construct one our clan will be awarded a permanent clan trait and its associated effects.

There are two types of rebellion. A general whose loyalty has dropped too low may attempt to form his own clan rather than defect to another. If this happens, he will raise an army and try to capture the nearest settlement. Riots amongst the peasants can also escalate into full-scale rebellions.

The wealth of a province is the sum of the base income generated by the settlement, farms, ports and province speciality buildings, minus tax. This net income is displayed in the lower left section of the province details panel. The lower right section shows the factors affecting the settlement's additional economic growth over the following turn and indeed every turn to come.
We are leaving our settlement undefended; doing so could lead to its capture and the destruction of the clan before our campaign has even begun!

The two dimensional "drawn" sections of the map are due to the fog of war. Although the positions of geographical features, borders and settlements are well known, without agents and fleets clans are nevertheless unaware of the movements of each other's forces and agents - often until it is too late! This is simulated by the fog of war. Use our forces to reveal the machinations of rivals before they act against us!
Information about any selected character, army, fleet, port or settlement is displayed here. In the case of armies and fleets their constituent units or ships are shown.

Upgrading the road system within a province will increase its trade capability. Better quality roads also increase the line of sight from both the road and the nearest settlement, improve the chances of detecting enemy agents, allow armies to march further within a turn and also speedily replenish their depleted units.

The daimyo is the leader of our clan and also a fine general. He can be given command of an army and sent into battle the same way as any other general. This of course means he can also be killed, so be careful not to expose him to unnecessary risks on the battlefield.

A daimyo does not have loyalty to the clan he leads, he has honour instead. If he loses honour this will in turn affect the loyalty of his generals. Factors that may cause loss of honour include: a crushing defeat of an army led by the daimyo, breaking a treaty or alliance, looting of settlements, or allowing a dishonoured general to live despite many failures or the risk of treason. Factors that increase the daimyos honour include: a heroic victory or destruction of a clan by an army led by the daimyo.

Details of victory conditions and missions are stored here. Each clan has a set of predetermined territorial conquests that it must complete in order to attain victory. These are displayed at the top of this tab. Click on a mission to check the time remaining for completion or read its details again.

A clan can demonstrate its commitment to a diplomatic agreement by offering a hostage as a guarantee. Any one of the daimyo's children, though not one that is a general, can be sent to another clan for a period of eight turns. If, at the end of this time, the deal has been honoured, the hostage will be returned. If the agreement is broken at any time the hostage will be killed.

You have selected a target outside the highlighted area. This means the character cannot reach his target this turn. Provided that an enemy does not block his path, he will continue on his journey during the next turn.
This piece cannot move any further now. It will be available again next turn.

An army that has been stationary for a turn is "dug in". This means they will have had time to prepare and deploy defences on the field if attacked. If the army is moved at any point during the same turn it will no longer be dug in if attacked.
There are not enough funds in our treasury to build anything this turn. Increase taxation and trade, or disband redundant armed forces to raise our income in the short-term.
Select the back button to return to the avatar conquest map.

Saga domain. Our clan, the Nabeshima, have long served as guardians of Nagasaki - Japan's only point of contact with westerners during its seclusion. As such, we have come to understand much of western technology and way of life. We will use this understanding to depose the Shogun and reinstate the Emperor for the good of Japan! Our first priority should be to establish ties with other Imperial loyalists on Kyushu whilst crushing those who still support the Shogunate. It is imperative that we then establish a navy, allowing us to support our allies on the mainland in their fight against the Shogunate; Kyoto and Edo must be brought under Imperial control! When full-scale war finally erupts between Imperial and Shogunate forces the people of Saga will be at the vanguard, leading Japan into a bright and glorious future. Long live the Emperor!

Tsu domain. The Todo clan has always chosen its allies wisely; at the battle of Sekigahara we threw in our lot with Tokugawa Ieyasu, the inevitable victor, and were rewarded with these lands at the heart of Honshu. It is time to join the winning side once more: the Shogunate is weak and support for Imperial rule grows stronger by the day. The Emperor has our support, then, but we must tread cautiously: we are surrounded by the Shogun's allies and would be foolish to wage war until we are stronger or have the support of others. We must then wrest control of Kyoto and Edo from the Shogunate to weaken their grip. When full-scale war finally erupts between Imperial and Shogunate forces the people of Tsu will be at the vanguard, leading Japan into a bright and glorious future. Long live the Emperor!

Sendai domain. Our heritage is rich, descendants of the mighty Date clan during the Sengoku Jidai. Although we have tried to maintain order, the Imperialists view our respect for the Shogunate as proof that we mean to wage war upon them. So be it then, we will give them war! Our first priority should be to rally support for the Shogun in the north. Once it is secured, we should join our allies to the southwest whilst ensuring the safety of Kyoto and Edo; should these seats of power fall into Imperialist hands, the battle will be all but over. When the combined forces of the Emperor move against the Shogun, they will find the people of Sendai standing resolute before them! For the Shogun!

Obama domain. Bound by blood to the Tokugawa clan, we - the Sakai - have always fought for the Shogun. Although we have tried to prevent conflict, our hand has been forced by the Imperialists' extreme methods. For the good of Japan, they must be stopped. Our first priority should be to subdue nearby threats before they are reinforced, as the Shogun's enemies will soon close in from the west, and we cannot afford to be surrounded. We must then join our allies to protect Kyoto and prevent Imperial forces from sweeping eastwards towards Edo; should these key cities fall to the enemy, the battle will be all but over. But the people of Obama will not falter; Japan's best interests will be defended! For the Shogun!

The Gatling gun is an early type of machine gun that works by the cranking of a handle that rotates multiple barrels, loads and then fires in the same moment. It can be controlled by you directly from a first person point of view at the cost of your control of other units of course! Gatling guns have a very high rate of fire, are highly accurate and can cause high damage. Its crew have a high morale but will be slaughtered if forced into melee.
Before looking at the main unit roster, let's take a closer look at the veteran unit you have recruited from the previous battle. Select the veterans tab.
Battle list mode, allows you to create your own customised battle against other human players.
While clan conquest, allows you to join or create a clan and fight with other players for control of Japan on an even greater scale. Japan is waiting to be conquered, go forth and wage Total War!
Press the back button to return to the conquest map and challenge the enemy again.
A new retainer has been unlocked and made available to you. Press the show retainers button to make use of this new reward.
A new unit has now been unlocked and made available to you.

Upon capturing all key buildings within a multiplayer battle a timer will begin to count down. Unless a key building changes hands during this time the owner(s) of these buildings will be awarded victory once time runs out.
You can switch between avatar profiles or create new ones by clicking on the swap avatar button on the toolbar.
Completing an armour set will unlock a prized retainer for your army.

Avatars can be promoted when they reach rank 10. This will raise their prestige. Prestige level can be ascertained from the colour of an avatar's ranking stars, starting at bronze and working up to diamond.
The archery dojo increases the reload rate of all missile units and restores ammunition supplies to nearby missile units.
The farmhouse increases the stamina and movement speed of all units.
The shrine increases the morale of all units.
The sword dojo increases the melee attack and charge of all units.
The workshop building increases the armour and melee defence of all units.
Clan leaders who own both Shogun 2 and Fall of the Samurai can select two clan speciality skills for their clan.
The clan competition offers a wide range of map filters, displaying vital information on the current status of each game world, and helping clans plot their path to victory.
By winning the clan competition or gaining promotion to a higher tier, clan members will receive a number of rewards with which to customise their avatars.
Joining a clan allows you to collect clan tokens each time you complete a battle. Clan tokens give access to specialist upgrades that improve veteran units and allow you to reset avatar skills.
The coastal battery automatically fires on any enemy in range.
Retainer filters can be used to narrow down the search for the ideal retainer.
Veteran filters can be used to search for specific veteran units to add to your army setup.
Veteran units who have taken casualties in battle must be left out of your army for one battle to regain their full strength.

In addition to the advisor and encyclopaedia, there are now comprehensive video tutorials in order to explain many basic aspects of the campaign, battle and multiplayer modes. They can be accessed at any time via the tutorials index in the encyclopaedia. Open the encyclopaedia with the dedicated button in the top left-hand corner of the campaign map or battlefield, or via the question mark buttons in the top right-hand corner of most panels.

Now that trade with foreign powers has been undertaken a trade route to that nation will appear on the map. The route disappears off the map in the direction of actual routes of the time, indicated by an arrow-shaped golden node. It is not possible to click on or interact with the node; it does not work the same way as trade posts in Shogun 2.

My fellow Jesuits landed recently on your shores, and found that we have much in common. We have our deep loyalty to the Holy Father in Rome. You have a deep loyalty to your daimyo and to the Shogun. Our loyalties have provoked others and made them enemies, for such is the way of the world. Now your country is in turmoil. The Shoguns authority wanes, and your own position is threatened by lesser men. Together, though, we can be strong. Trade with us brings you the strength of God, wealth, and guns to arm the righteous. The lands of your old rivals, the Ouchi, are near. Seize them, punish your rivals, and gain a foothold on the mainland. The Shimazu resent the favour you enjoy in the eyes of the Shogunate and the close friendship we have between us. Be wary of them, for their delusions of superiority will make them determined to see you crushed. Be vigilant, and all will be well. The heathens will be brought to the Lamb, or they will be destroyed. By Gods grace, the Otomo will prevail!

Flashing white banners mean your line is wavering and the troops close to breaking and routing. Use your general's inspiration ability to keep them in the fight a little longer. Some elite infantry types can also inspire courage in nearby comrades.

The clan is bankrupt, but we could reverse this situation and increase income by setting up new trade routes. This is done via the negotiation of trade agreements through the diplomatic negotiations panel.
This tab lists all agents currently operating in our clan, their available action points, current positions and names. It can be sorted by each of those headings.
A fight between two spear-equipped infantry units usually comes down to troop quality and numbers. Make sure you have local superiority - or send in some supporting troops.
When defending a river crossing it may be best to stand back in order to stay out of range of enemy missile troops. When their main force starts to cross, rush a couple of units up to stop them.
Pressing this button cancels orders and makes selected units or ships stop where they are. This is a quicker alternative to giving them a different order.
Watch your finances when recruiting units: samurai are expensive! Every turn you must pay upkeep costs: a large army can lead to bankruptcy.
Master, one of our land trade routes is under attack from an enemy army. Without intervention they will continue to raid and take our goods and income for themselves.

Money can be offered to or demanded of another clan as reparations for war, tribute to avoid attack, or simply as an act of goodwill. Use the arrow buttons to enter an amount and click on the appropriate check box in order to select a single or regular payment before putting forward our proposal.

The construction tab shows all buildings and structures in Tosa province. Mouse over these to see new buildings you can construct. There is an empty construction site in your castle town; move the cursor over it. Select the archery range that now appears.
If your army has superiority in terms of firepower you may be able to force a defender off the hill with missiles alone. Use all your ammunition before assaulting the hill.

With extra income from trade and your army at Iyo getting replenishments, it is time to move against another province. A large force will be needed to capture Sanuki province. Improve your army with more units before attempting any expedition to Sanuki.

Units with banners that have turned white are routing - they have broken and are running away, and won't follow any more of your orders. If positioned close by, your general may be able to rally these troops with his special ability. If successful you'll regain control of them.
There are currently no troops stationed in this province, leaving it open to conquest by an aggressive neighbour.

Wedge formation increases the violence of a cavalry charge. Intended to drive a wedge through the enemy unit and cause maximum casualties, this formation is also useful for charging through narrow gaps. Select wedge formation using the button on the battle control panel.

A cavalry unit moving quickly across the field of fire is not a sensible target for missile units. You may kill a few enemies, but better look instead for a tightly-packed target unit, one at a standstill, or coming head-on to your guns.
This option is used to ask a clan to abandon their alliance with another, preventing dangerous coalitions from emerging against us.

This panel gives information about how a building's effects work in the game, along with a detailed description of its function. Some buildings allow you to construct other, more advanced ones - so it's worth reading all the information here and checking the encyclopaedia too.

On the Chosokabe family tree select Chikayasu's portrait. Now click on the commission buttons to give him a commission and its bonuses. Only male adults in the family or promoted generals can be given a commission. Your general's loyalty will improve, and the clan as a whole benefits.
Shikoku will be ruled by one clan! Soon you must visit the mainland of Honshu in search of further wealth and resources.

To place an army or character on board a ship or fleet select it and hover your mouse over the fleet. The cursor will change into an arrow with a figure - illustrating that the ship or fleet can be boarded. Right-click to board.

The treasury indicates the amount of money in the clan's coffers and is displayed next to the projected income for the next season. The number in the bottom corner of the screen represents our clans food supply. Farms produce food and castles consume it. A food surplus helps a castle town grow; when food supply is at zero, then supply and demand are equal. A minus number indicates a food shortage, so it is vitally important to keep producing as much food as possible to keep that number positive and therefore decrease the likelihood of unrest.
Your people are happier and more prosperous now that their taxes are lower. The province's economy looks strong once more. However, a new threat is emerging
Hiding stronger units to the rear may entice the enemy into a rash attack. They can then be brought up quickly to attack the weakest point.

Following capture of a castle town, it is important to leave an adequate garrison behind to quell unrest until both the population level and any damaged buildings are fully restored. Exempting the province from tax may also be helpful in the short-term.
The run button is used to toggle selected units between running and walking. Running is useful for going somewhere in a hurry, but doing it too much will tire the men out.

Now we have a ship or fleet capable of trade select a trade post near the edge of the map - as indicated by the anchor icon - and right-click on it to go there. Trading commences when our fleet's flag flashes with the yellow coin graphic.

Master, our port has been blockaded by an enemy fleet. This does not affect our ability to build new ships or repair existing combat-damaged ships, but all trade income through it will be suspended for the life of the blockade. Attack the enemy fleet to break out and restore trade.

The two dimensional parts of the map are caused by the fog of war. Although the positions of geographical features, borders and some castle towns are well known, without agents and fleets clans are nevertheless unaware of the movements of each other's forces and agents - often until it is too late! This is simulated by the fog of war. We must use our forces to reveal the machinations of rivals before they act against us!
Master! There is an armed rebellion occurring in a neighbouring province! This wave of insurrection may reach our territory, we must guard against it by increasing garrison sizes or reducing taxes.
The manoeuvre compass is used for fine-tuning orders. The three arrows within its top half can be used to direct a unit, ship or group straight ahead, or turn left or right.

Units can be recruited directly by a general in the field. Select the recruitment tab, then left-click on a unit to add it to the queue and again to remove it. When ready, units will walk to the appropriate general and merge with his army. Note that units can only walk directly to the general, they are not able to cross the sea to join him.

This panel shows statistical information about the selected province. The bottom section shows the factors contributing to the local and clan economy; the middle section shows the elements affecting, and status of, public order; the top section deals with food supply, the province's speciality resource and a breakdown of religious beliefs.

A province's castle town is the central settlement within it. As the main administrative centre, it contains a castle as well as trade and military buildings. Castle towns are the main consumer of food supplies in a province, so it is vitally important to keep agricultural buildings upgraded to avoid food shortages.
This army is now in a position to ambush passing enemies. However, be aware that hidden enemies can ambush our own armies in just the same way!

When using light infantry or skirmishers to force light troops to retreat behind their lines, be careful not to chase them too far. Do not risk getting dragged into a fight with their frontline units.

Fire-at-will for missiles can be toggled on or off with the button in the bottom left-hand corner of the screen. Keeping it toggled off will help preserve ammunition, but then our units or ships will only fire when specifically ordered.
Repairing buildings takes time and money, but the structure regains its former glory and usefulness.

During an attack on a castle town, the attackers and defenders have many options in common. The attackers can also besiege a castle and, given time, starve the enemy into submission. This time, you must be swift! Capture the castle now: eliminate the wretched, treacherous Kono.

So: the clan's taxes are at maximum level, making your people unhappy; the province is shown in red on the radar map. Move the tax slider in the middle of the panel to the left until the province is no longer shown in red.

Pressing the space bar on your keyboard after orders have been issued displays the positions your units will move to as a shadow on the battlefield. Use this as a reference when deploying your forces.
Information about any selected character, army, fleet, port or castle town is displayed here. In the case of armies and fleets their constituent units or ships are shown.

Awa has fallen. You now have the finest horses in Japan at your disposal. Make use of the horses by constructing dojos alongside stables so you can recruit bow, yari and katana cavalry. You are now a fearsome leader indeed, and the end of your tuition is nigh. Go! Make the Chosokabe a great power on the mainland!

Upgrading the road system within a province will increase its trade capability. Better quality roads also increase the line of sight from both the road and the nearest castle town, improve the chances of detecting enemy agents, allow armies to march further within a season and also speedily replenish their depleted units.
The Chosokabe army is battered after defeating the Motoyama; Tosa relies on its inhabitants for defence. Select the recruitment tab on the province panel; it is time to restore the army's strength.
The Kono and Miyoshi clans are not on good terms with the Chosokabe. You cannot be certain what the Kono monk is planning, it would be wise to recruit another samurai archer unit to defend Tosa.
You are running out of money. Increase taxes, disband some units or scupper some ships so that your net income improves next turn.

The enemy will try to either sneak past our defences or rush them by force of arms. Use archers to kill approaching enemies and melee troops to kill those that get into the castle compound! The enemy will try to wipe out all defenders, and if our men rout en masse from the castle the battle is over.
Always try to present a solid wall of troops to the enemy. Large gaps between units will let them flood through and behind your units, which would be disastrous.

Take the initiative in battle by making manoeuvres the enemy must respond to. Even if you don't follow it through, they'll be so busy countering your moves they'll have no time to make any of their own.

The boarding button orders our ship to close with the target vessel and sends an armed group aboard to capture it. Boarding actions call for a high degree of skill and courage in the troops taking part, and can be cancelled at any time by de-selecting the button or issuing another order.
The diplomacy panel lets you view your diplomatic standing with neighbouring clans. You can also make new deals: resources and wealth can be traded. Now, select the Matsuda clan to begin diplomacy.
Master, there are not enough funds in our treasury to build anything this season. Increase taxation and trade, or disband redundant armed forces to raise our income in the short-term.

The battle timer shows how much time is left before the battle ends. The attacker must rout or destroy the defender within the time limit or lose the battle. To claim victory the defender has only to keep the attacker at bay, so can still win, even if outnumbered.

Rival agents can be removed by assassination. Select a target for your ninja to kill. Decide if the chance of success is worth the risk before confirming the order, as failure may mean capture and execution.
